topic.title: yacy.net Decentralized Web Search project
topic.body:
Imagine if, rather than relying on the proprietary software of a large professional search engine operator, your search engine was run by many private computers which aren't under the control of any one company or individual. Well, that's what YaCy does! 

https://www.yacy.net/

1540796902_148DXj745fSuMtCnbh3uJnb3Tm4Zb.body:
It would be nice if there were a modular framework or platform that functioned in a similar way to Joomla which less skilled website owners and creators can use easily. Content is key to wider adoption and people wont create content if it's too difficult and for the most part the best content creators aren't the most skilled developers and vis versa.

I have been watching Znet for the past year or so because I have a need to move a community off the clear net. There are several barriers one basic core functionality is lacking for someone of my skill level, and two ease of use for users/community members who have very little technical skills and are reluctant to radical change.

Documentation is a bit lacking for new site owners coming from a traditional hosting environment and lamp/wamp stack, who have limited coding and system level administration skills imho. Some of the documentation seems to assume a certain level of understanding, which we don't all have especially anyone coming from a Win environment.

Personally I'm kind of stuck at the moment trying to get my ZeroFish Docker installation functioning fully on a Synology nas. I haven't had time to reach out for help yet, so I cant complain, because I'm sure the community here will point me in the right direction when asked. Having said that I should really be able to figure it out using documentation or user guides on my own.

Once I manage to do that I will face the problem of developing a site that functions like a traditional forum and CMS, that allows easy content creation, admin and user management. It will also need to be simple for community members to interact on the forum, search and user content and thread management being quite important. A private messaging system would also be useful imho, although ZeroMail could fill that gap initially.

Is it possible to run an instance of ZeroMail as a private community service rather than relying on the global Zmail service?

It would be nice if there was a standard global text editor like tinymce or something to help users create content with basic html, css and formatting etc.

I haven't attempted clone and develop a site yet, one because I need to get my installation functional, and two I haven't really come across an easy guide to follow that explains some of the quirks and pitfalls to avoid for an idiot like me.

Another issue is what do we do with all the years of content we all ready have out there on the clear net? Obviously we can continue to maintain the existing site in the short term, but ideally that content would be brought over to preserve historical information and research etc. Is it going to be possible to export and migrate sql data tables from say a forum to a Znet site?

For example would it be possible to build static/archive type framework that has all the basic required fields to support something like a phpBB forum or Wordpress, Drupal or Joomla site, with migration tools?

I'm not a developer and I'm not particularly smart, but I am and have been very aware of the dangers we face with respect to the future of free speech, privacy, security and governmental/corporate control, and I want to find a viable solution. So far Zeronet seems like the best solution on many levels, although scaleability is a concern.

Would it be possible to establish a dedicated core dev team that could build a standardised generic platform, with modular aspects like skinning, admin panel, site level user management etc. similar to Joomla and it's user created extensions for example? Maybe with features and goals/milestones which users can vote for and then fund the development of? Or is that wishful thinking on my part?

Sorry for the long and rambling post which is probably a bit disjointed. Hopefully I managed to make a useful and valid point here and there?

My big concern is the fact that time to make a transition is running out fast, especially in Europe! We need to be encouraging large numbers of users over from the clear net asap imho. To do that we need nicely presented and easy to access content, that's accessible securely across a range of devices.

> [andreas](#comment_2_16ExhLrK3XmMRhe7XWHJYHdJZa6JnzHr6R): Isn't it clear what they mean? Gab got dropped because they were a hub for the alt-right. No reason to open our arms wide to these people and offer them ZeroNet as our alternative, unless we want to end up with the same reputation as 4Chan or Gab

So you're for an exclusion policy or censorship by other means? Free speech provided it is in line with my views and opinions?

Steps back and awaits the cries of Nazi etc. from anonymous clowns on the internet, simply for expressing and opinion and appreciating the fact that free speech should be open to all opinions or it effectively applies to none.

1542317704_17AMQVbBa12XB3xFWKDnP2dCEx92T.body:
Maybe it's because people are exploring the technology and simply move on after a time?

The key is to attract content creators and currently Znet is too challenging for your average creator types. The exception would be those using the system out of necessity, due to censorship and awareness of the impending clamp down which is ramping up, especially in Europe.

Some comprehensive user guides on Ytube might help teach people enough to give them confidence to give Znet a go? Most of what's on Ytube is old and doesn't really go into the nitty gritty of actually using Znet in real world use cases. Many Znet videos on Ytube don't even have dialogue which makes it difficult to follow.

Education is vital imho because people need to know how to do basics, like backing up their configs and general management. There needs to be walk throughs that go through the cloning process, simple site edits and other routine tasks.

Ytube may not be the best choice either Dtube and bitchute might have an audience more likely to investigate Znet more seriously?

The other problem is attracting an audience over to Znet to consume content. Mobile phone usage is probably an issue as managing a Znet installation isn't practical on a phone. More proxys would probably help overcome that to an extent. 

I don't think there is a simple answer beyond the rate of adoption and natural wastage. Znet still seems rather experimental and has a number of quirks, which probably leads to a low rate of long term adopters.

> [ornataweaver](#comment_62_139zVkd4AsZqs9qSYk6ypPDAqDcjPCmRm4): I agree that we should attract content creators.Do you think making a patreon center here would help?

Imho the most effective way to attract content creators would be to make it easy for them to create content. It's a bit of a chicken 'n egg deal because they create content for an audience, so we also need to raise awareness among content consumers. Before any of that can happen we need developers to deliver the tools to make life easy for us none developer types. Maybe what we need is some way of encouraging devs to build the tools people need first. Not being a developer I can't say what insensitive is required? Especially on this type of platform because there's a major morality/principle component with respect to freedoms etc. This type of platform is something the world needs in the face of overreaching government controls and censorship. That's a big incentive in itself for many I'm sure.

I also don't know how organised the development process is? Defined road maps with clear goals and completion dates would be useful, especially if non tech types can have some input as to what they feel are priorities for usability etc. via polls and maybe even some form of donations system for completed goals?

I don't know the answers but hopefully together we can make it happen.

I just had a thought...would it be possible to create a tool that would pull content from say an existing WPress site or similar and post it into a Znet site? If not automated some simple manual process?

Apart from anonymity Zent offers the ability to create publicly accessible content at virtually zero cost, i.e. no domain fees and more importantly no hosting fees and TOS. Effectively it could be used as a free mirror and backup site. It should be an easy sell based on those incentives imho.

Something like that may short circuit the content creation process, because it's not an all out adoption from the get go, and hopefully over time creators would migrate over as Znet establishes a stronger presence.

Just a thought.

I think it would also be good to maintain a presence on the clear net because that's where the potential audience resides right now. I have actively looked for Znet content on the web and it's scant and mostly a year or so old. How about an active Ytube Znet channel with regular updates on development, tips and trick, new site promotions etc. some kind of news channel or something? We need to create a buzz to stimulate interest.

@krombopulusmike 

No, I said that 'moderation of a forum is NOT censorship of the platform'. I.e. the host of the forum has a choice as to what is relevant on that forum. If a member of that forum feels they were censored they have the ability to create their own forum on the same platform, in order to freely express their opinion, and expose the other forum. The host of the original forum doesn't have the ability to censor the aggrieved party on the forum they create to expose them.

A forum is the equivalent to an individuals home and the platform is the public square. Preventing free speech in the public square would equate to censorship, because it restricts individuals from presenting their views freely to a broad audience (the public). A forum is an area open to individuals who choose to participate in a discussion within a group that has boundaries, established to maintain civilised relevant discourse.

Imho, it's not my responsibility to decide what others should think whether they are weak minded or intellectual giants. It's up to me to present my opinions supported by evidence and reason in a way that may help others understand my views, so that they may use that information to form their own opinion on the matter.

Moderation is about keeping the conversation relevant, on topic and within the bounds of civil debate.

Censorship is about the removal of content which maybe be deemed objectionable based on political, ethical, moral and military grounds etc.

Both maybe open to abuse. The issue here is context with respect to censorship in its extreme, in order to eliminate opinions and ideas. Moderation on the Zeronet platform is limited to the owner of the site/forum and not the entire platform. A moderator can't censor others using the platform, there is a distinct difference, which you and other seem to fail to grasp!

Here's a very simple example of the concept:

Your mum decides to create a forum for women in her local community and she lays out the rules of membership.
Membership is open to local women of all ages, to discuss knitting, sewing, gardening and general women's issues.

Some Guy from a neighboring town decides to join the group, and he starts opening topics about satanism, male prostrate cancer and engine tuning etc.

Your mum removes his irrelevant topics, and reminds the guy about the rules and scope of the forum. All of which he had failed to comply with!

The guy is disgusted at being treated that way and accuses your mother of censoring him.

Your mother explains that he was aware of the conditions of using the forum when he joined, while informing him that he is free to open his own forum to discuss the topics which interest him.

The guy creates his own forum and posts content explaining how badly treated he was by your mother.

Your mother takes offense at the accusations and post a rebuttal on his site along with her own. 

The guy deletes your mothers post from his site, while your mothers site still presents her argument on her site.

Neither of them can censor the other as they are only in control of the data on their own site/forum! 

Ipso facto the platform offers uncensored free speech, while individual sites may moderate the material they host as they see fit.

ZeroNet offers freedom to the users to create and host their own sites, which they are free to maintain as they see fit.

That is my argument, not the nonsense that you are attempting to attribute to me!

As for your OP I could question your motives based on the logic or lack there of in your argument.

You have created a strawman argument that is attempting to associate multiple parties to some conspiratorial plot to undermine freedom of speech aspect of the Zeronet platform. You have intentionally engineered your strawman to draw geekless into your your narrative, in order to accuse him of plotting to undermine the ZN platform. You have provided zero evidence that geekless has any association with any other party! Furthermore it could be argued that you are intentionally trying to engineer a situation that undermines the development of the ZeroTalk ++ project, and by extension the health and growth of the entire ZN platform.

The moderator functions which geekless has included in his ZeroTalk ++ project are not there for the purpose of censoring the ZN platform. To make such a claim is delusional at best and downright dishonest in reality. The moderator features are user definable and the impact of the moderation is limited to the individual forum created by the individual user.

The only aspect of your accusations that has any merit in the slightest is your claim that there is some form of organised contributory effort by two or more of the parties identified by yourself.  Which is hardly a revelation nor a display of cunning detective work. It's pretty obvious that there are connections between two or more parties based on the use of language, posting styles etc. Most people should be able to determine that there is a group effort involved or an individual with multiple accounts trying to game the system. It's hardly something new to ZN, it's a pattern of human behavior which predates the internet ffs! 

Your post isn't the first that has attempted to accuse geekless and discourage him from developing his project. That seem like a far more troubling situation, given how active the development of ZeroTalk ++ has been and how functional it is becoming. Zeronet needs a functional forum to encourage contributors and build communities, so I have to question your real motives in attempting to damage the progress of geekless's work!?

From my perspective you are intentionally attempting to make unfounded association between geekless and other parties with the intention of harming the progress of ZeroTalk ++. > [test12365](#comment_1_17DFecT1rUtpofyfEvapNqRtkZ7J86M4H4): Socialism is an improvement over capitalism. Why don't people grasp that ? [...]

Because that statement is fundamentally untrue. The reality is that there has not been a truly free capitalist system, the closest it may have come was probably the late 1700 and 1800's. Primarily during the development of the industrial revolution. When it was possible for individuals to develop ideas and bring them to local/national markets independently, without overreaching legislation etc. The legislation crept in to restrict independent businesses from expanding, and allow larger organisations to form monopolies which could afford the expenses required to comply with  legislation. Today many large corporations actually create the legislation required to protect their interests via lobbying etc. The monopolies simply buy out individual and family owned businesses, hoovering up innovation either for profit or to prevent new ideas/products from impacting existing profitable markets.

1628996725_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRF.body:
OnePlus 6T 128/256GB - de-googled Linage with F-droid should pick up a OP6T 256 for £200 ish in UK.

No MicroSD unfortunately.

The ease of De-googleing the OP6 was the biggest draw for me, plus I don't want a 5G phone. I'm not a heavy smart phone user...my main phone is an old Nokia 6230i. I also have a de-googled OP3T which is still very usable.

Moving data off the OP6 to an external drive isn't exactly a chore, and way better than keeping data on the phone or in the cloud imho.

There are newer OnePlus models available, with more bells and whistles, but de-googleing them may not be as well supported as the OP6 (I haven't kept up with latest developments). A OP6 is a pretty snappy phone and for £200 it's hard to beat. The Dual sim is also something I find useful.

Other negatives the screen is bonded to the body, and the battery is built-in, so replacement is not as easy as it was on older models. The camera isn't as good as those on high end flagship phones, although it does a decent enough job imho. It's not fully waterproof.

There are some compromises if you go the de-googles FOSS route, especially if you rely on some of the popular apps on Google Play. If you install GAPS things get a little easier, at the expense of exposing your data to Google and App developers etc.
